captions.text:
When you have an idea
and something begins to take shape
- and the more you think about it, the more you realise that this could be a really viable idea.

It starts, in yourself initially,
to take on a certain momentum of its own.
How do I build a car?
How can someone that loves to drive get from A to B
with a clear conscience?
We need to change,
and we need to fundamentally question everything we have done over the last years and decades

if we want to survive and remain
competitive in the future.

Others paint flowers or dabble in sculpting,
take photos of whatever,

and I use ink to draw up
blueprints of cars on transparent paper.

The person is at the centre here
and that's where you start.

You place them, as it were, in an empty mock-up room
and then start to build the whole car around this person.
I remember seeing the design planned out as a complete vehicle for the first time
and I knew right away – even if this seemed like a crazy idea - that it might just be possible to build it.
Lots of people have ideas, but innovation only happens when a group of people
come together to share their ideas.
Of course, there are some truly amazing moments along the way.
Like when the vehicle is started for the very first time or when it takes its first spin on the test track,
And with so many technical functions that have to be implemented in a vehicle like this,
it is sort of like teaching it how to walk, step by step.
The wonderful thing is that the character of this car is the product of all the love, dedication
and know-how that goes into building it, and this is reflected in the car and the way it drives.

This character, you can also feel it
when you drive the car.
I strongly believe that we at Vision EfficientDynamics have really hit the mark with this car.

When the car is then finished, you mentally
begin to say your good-byes.
It’s kind of like coming to the end of a good book, a little bit like losing a friend.
And it’s the same with a car like this.
My name is Jürgen Greil and I’m a mechanical engineer at BMW.

@desimunda116 well your assumption is correct. i have thought the same. 
although if a car is supposed to be efficient the most common and effective 
method is downsizing. downsizing means to take cylinders out to save weight 
and minimize friction. taking out cylinders means losing sound especially 
when talking 4 cylinder engines which are mostly used in downsized cars. i 
think there is basically NO current 4 cyl engine which can compare to a.. 
say.. 8 cyl?

comments.text:
@dpain0 What he meant by ''coming to an end of a good book'' was HIS 
journey designing, engineering and building the VED has ended and thus he 
has to say goodbye to it as it will be in production which is no longer his 
job, as like he said sort of like losing a friend after all the good 
memories together. When that settles down, then he will start another whole 
new journey with another new car, with a new book and sort of like getting 
a new friend. I hope you understand =)

comments.text:
This is why I love BMW so much. Like the other Unscripted vid with Murray, 
this is what you feel. When you're driving along you feel the dedication 
that these members of BMW put into the cars they build. You can feel that 
love, affection, and care. It's very technical but also human in its own 
way. This is what you feel every time you start it put it into gear and 
drive off. That is why BMW is the Ultimate Driving Machine! Cheers!
comments.author: JDBMW1
